The light ray travels from A to O1 (on the boundary) and then refracts to pass through B. Since O1 is on the boundary (y = 0), its coordinates are O1 = (x_{O1}, 0). The problem states that O1 is to the right of O, which means x_{O1} > 0, since O is at (0, 0). Our task is to verify if this statement aligns with the physics of refraction.
The path of the light is: From A in air to O1 on the boundary (incident ray). From O1 to B in water (refracted ray).

The light ray goes from air (less dense medium) to water (denser medium), so it will bend toward the normal at O1. Snell’s Law governs refraction: n_1 sin θ_i = n_2 sin θ_r, where n_1: Refractive index of air (≈ 1), n_2: Refractive index of water (≈ 1.33), θ_i: Angle of incidence (angle between the incident ray AO1 and the normal at O1), θ_r: Angle of refraction (angle between the refracted ray O1B and the normal at O1). Since n_2 > n_1, the light bends toward the normal, meaning θ_r < θ_i.
The normal at O1 is perpendicular to the boundary. Since the boundary is the x-axis (y = 0), the normal is along the y-axis (vertical).
